text: hi everyone anthony fantano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of the new ben frost
album aurora this guy is an australian
music producer multi-instrumentalist and
soundtrack composer lately he has been
keeping busy putting together film
scores as well as a collaboration with
daniel bjarnsen but it's been a while
since we've last heard from ben in a
full-length studio album capacity 2009's
by the throat by my count an album that
not only dabbled in the very moody dark
ambient soundscapes and drones that we
typically expected from ben but also
chamber music there were some pretty
intricate compositions on this record as
well as a little bit of
abrasiveness noisiness by the throat is
a really diverse and skilled album i
recommend you listen to it however this
latest project from ben is not nearly as
diverse in fact i think he very
intentionally
narrows his scope down to the more
synthetic and harsh elements of ben's
compositional palette on this lp ben is
embracing heavy industrially tinged
rhythms shrouded in harsh walls of noise
little baby high-pitched squelched
melodies hidden away in apocalyptic fuzz
i love dark ambient music like this that
is incredibly textured the two latest
tim hecker records actually come to mind
both of which might actually have been
influenced by ben frost to a degree
given that the 2009 album by the throat
was so distorted and was so textured and
tim hecker actually named it as one of
his favorite records of the year on
self-titled magazine's website still
admittedly though
i am feeling just a tad underwhelmed by
this new ben frost record for music that
is ambient music experimental music
noise music there are very few moments
on this lp where i feel
mystified where i feel like i'm being
brought to another world this music to
me doesn't really have that strong of a
sense of place what i mean to say is is
this record i i kind of just see right
through it for what it is it's just
pretty transparent a little uninspiring
i think the sounds on this lp as they
are presented to me
they don't really drive me to
imagine or really feel anything the
sounds are just merely the sounds and
throughout the duration of this record
to me they just kind of stay that way
that might have to do with the
composition of these songs but supremely
i think it has a lot to do with the flow
of this album which i think is terrible
there's nothing significant in my
opinion about how the tracks on this lp
complement one another this thing to me
really feels like just a mixed bag the
first half of the lp for example is
loaded with these whisper quiet ambient
tracks i would actually even call the
third track on this lp almost a field
recording not only are these tracks not
that gripping it seems like they're both
really too short to elicit any kind of
sense of calm but it seems like the only
reason these songs are in the track list
is just so that the next track
immediately after them can bust in with
an incredibly loud intro that's ear
piercing in comparison in volume this
happens from the song flex to the song
nolan this happens from the teeth to
secant this happens within the very
short track on this lp diabetal oxalate
and while i don't really mind jarring
music i found at least in this case on
this record
it just sort of lost its luster as i was
listening to this album repeated times
now as far as the louder tracks on this
lp go separately i wouldn't even call
them that interesting the song nolan for
example is incredibly chaotic with all
these drums bells synthesizer leads a
drone hanging in the background too i
think and none of it really ever
assembles into anything coherent what
ends up happening is the song just turns
quiet and slowly progresses into a
really loud massive brittle and
distorted finish a finish that's not
nearly as epic or overpowering as it is
just
shrill and kind of tedious i feel the
same way about the closing track on this
lp2 and as far as the song secant goes
this song to me seems more focused there
are huge massive drums on this track and
rumbling sub bass the rhythm on this
song just the chilling reverb
surrounding these drums reminds me of
like an old old early early swans track
but again as the song progresses we get
louder we get louder we get more intense
and we end up having a track that once
again is really shrill is really ear
piercing but the composition that the
distortion is masking or over modulating
just isn't incredibly gripping it kind
of underwhelms me in the same way that
when i listen to
let's say a sleigh bell song it's an
okay pop rock song but for whatever
reason it's just turned up to maximal
distorted volume for a bit of a thrill
on the second half of this lp there is
my favorite song on the album venter
another slow burner that picks up some
wintery drones and some bells along the
way the way this song is paced actually
reminds me of like a moment or two from
swans the seer and while the ending of
this song is noisy i do find it to be
more tolerable than some of the other
tracks on here but even the moments i
like on this lp i just find them to be
wrapped up far too much in their own
chaos like the explosions the distortion
the destruction the decay
that you hear on this record it's
encased into the album and it really
only affects itself and i'm just an
outside observer and it's just really
not translating to me i do commend this
album for its experimentation i do
commend ben for doing something
different this time around i commend
this record for just embracing the
tenets of of noise which is usually an
element i find interesting especially on
music such as this but i didn't find
this record to be even half
as cinematic or as engaging as ben's
last lp i'm feeling a strong five to a
light six on this album tran position if
you've given this record a listen what
did you think of it did you love it did
you hate it why what do you think i
should review next and that's it
ben frost aurora forever
